choices.text: Age of viability is 24 weeks of IUL
Ossification centre is present in talus
Meconium is found in the duodenum

questions.text: Which of the following sentence(s) is/are TRUE regarding age of viability?
questions.solution:
• Age of Viability in India is 28 weeks of IUL, indicating the earliest point at which a fetus may survive outside the womb with medical assistance.
  • Ossification center in talus develops by the end of the seventh month of IUL, indicating significant skeletal development.
  • Foetus weighs 700 gm at the end of the sixth month of IUL, correlating with typical fetal growth patterns.
  • Meconium in the duodenum appears by the end of the fourth month, showing early digestive system activity.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Age of Viability is 24 weeks IUL: Incorrect, as 28 weeks is the recognized viability threshold in India, allowing for the potential for survival.
  • C) Foetus weighs 700 gm: This weight is characteristic of the sixth month and does not pertain directly to the age of viability.
  • D) Meconium is found in the duodenum: Presence of meconium by the fourth month signifies early gastrointestinal development, not related to viability.

Key Takeaways:

  • Age of Viability in India is 28 weeks IUL, where external survival is possible with intervention.
  • Ossification centers are critical markers of fetal skeletal development, appearing by the seventh month.
  • Fetal weight at 700 gm reflects typical growth but not viability status.
  • Meconium presence in the duodenum is an indicator of digestive system maturation, occurring before viability.

questions.text: What is the age at which the gender of the foetus can be determined?
questions.solution:
• The gender of the fetus can be accurately determined at 16 weeks of gestation.
  • At this stage, the fetal length is approximately 16 cm and the weight is around 120 g.
  • Lanugo hair begins to appear on the body, providing insulation.
  • The pupillary membrane is visible, indicating early eye development.
  • Meconium is present in the upper part of the small intestine, signifying gastrointestinal activity.
  • Fingerprints are formed, marking the development of unique identity features.
  • Buds for all 20 temporary teeth have been laid down, indicating dental development.

Why Not Others:

  • A) 12 weeks: At this stage, external genitalia are not fully developed enough to determine gender.
  • C) 10 weeks: The reproductive organs are still in the early developmental stage, making gender determination impossible.
  • D) 14 weeks: While some structures may begin to form, gender differentiation is not clear until about 16 weeks.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gender determination of the fetus occurs at 16 weeks of gestation.
  • Key developmental milestones at this stage include visible lanugo hair, pupillary membrane, and the presence of meconium.
  • Understanding these developmental indicators aids in prenatal assessment and counseling.

choices.text: It is white, creamy, naturally occurring biofilm covering the skin of the foetus during the last trimester of pregnancy.
It contains water-containing corneocytes embedded in a lipid matrix.
Absence of vernix caseosa is useful sign to determine live birth
Hospital needs to preserve vernix caseosa for DNA analysis

questions.text: Which of the following statement/s is/are FALSE regarding vernix caseosa?
questions.solution:
• Vernix Caseosa Characteristics:
    • White, creamy biofilm: Covers fetus's skin during the last trimester.
    • Composition: Contains water-containing corneocytes in a lipid matrix, providing skin protection
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Absence indicates washing: Absence suggests the infant may have been washed after birth, indicating survival.
  • DNA Analysis:
    • Not preserved for DNA: Hospitals do not need to preserve vernix caseosa; blood samples are used for DNA analysis.

Why Not Others:

  • A) True: Vernix caseosa is indeed a biofilm covering the fetus's skin.
  • B) True: It contains water-containing corneocytes in a lipid matrix.
  • C) True: Absence can indicate the child had been washed, which may imply live birth but is not a definitive sign.

Key Takeaways:

  • Vernix caseosa protects the fetus and contains unique cellular structures.
  • Its absence can imply the infant had been washed, not directly indicating viability.
  • Blood is preferred for DNA analysis, making the preservation of vernix unnecessary.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2763724/#:~:text=Vernix%20caseosa%20is%20a%20white,not%20washed%20away%20after%20birth.

choices.text: Pieces of lung float - respired lung
Pieces of liver float - respired lung

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the Raygat's test?
questions.solution:
• Raygat's Test Overview:
    • Purpose: To determine whether fetal lungs have respired.
    • Procedure:
      • Dissect fetal lungs and tie them at the hilar region.
      • Place both lungs and a small piece of liver (control) in water.
  • Interpretation:
    • Lungs Float: Indicates respired lung.
    • Lungs Sink: Indicates unrespired lung.
  • Control:
    • If the liver floats, the test is invalid.
  • Fallacies:
    • False Positive: Can occur with putrefaction due to gas accumulation or artificial inflation.
    • False Negative: Can occur with atelectasis, obstruction, edema, feeble respiration, pneumonia, and congenital syphilis.

Why Not Others:

  • A) True: Floating lungs indicate they have respired.
  • C) True: Atelectasis leads to false negatives because non-expanded lungs may sink.
  • D) True: Putrefaction can lead to false positives due to gas accumulation.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Raygut test assesses lung respiration status in fetal autopsy.
  • Liver pieces should not float; a floating liver indicates a failed control test.
  • False negatives and positives are important considerations for accurate interpretation.

questions.text:
Which of the following sentences is FALSE regarding Cephalhematoma?
a. Swelling due to stagnation of fluid between layers of the scalp
b. Usually unilateral
c. Not limited to suture line
d. It is never present at birth
questions.solution:
Key Features of Cephalhematoma vs. Caput Succedaneum:


Why Not Others:

  • A) False: Cephalhematoma is not due to fluid stagnation; it involves blood accumulation.
  • B) True: Cephalhematoma is typically unilateral.
  • C) False: It is limited to the suture line, unlike caput succedaneum.
  • D) True: Cephalhematoma is never present at birth.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cephalhematoma is characterized by blood collection between the skull and periosteum, usually unilateral and limited to the suture line.
  • It develops after birth and is not present at birth, unlike caput succedaneum, which is a fluid collection present at birth.

choices.text: It is also called Caffey-Kempe syndrome
More common with female children below 3 years of age
Infantile whiplash syndrome is an example
Often injuries in different stages of healing are found

questions.text: Which of the following sentences is FALSE regarding Battered Baby Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Battered Baby Syndrome Overview:

  • Definition: A condition where a child suffers repeated physical injuries due to non-accidental violence by a parent or guardian.
  • Also Known As: Caffey syndrome, Caffey-Kempe syndrome, maltreatment syndrome, or parent-infant traumatic stress syndrome-often missed as a cause of pediatric trauma.

Key Points:

  • Age: Majority of cases occur in children below 3 years of age.
  • Sex: More common in male children (M:F ratio is 2:1).
  • Child Status: Frequently involves illegitimate or unwanted children, often the eldest or youngest, sometimes with mental subnormality.
  • Parental History: Parents often provide vague explanations for injuries, such as falls, that do not match the injury severity or timing.
  • Medical Attention: Parents tend to seek help late when the child's condition becomes serious.
  • Healing Stages: Injuries in different stages of healing are commonly observed, indicating repeated trauma.
  • CNS Injuries: Caused by actions like throwing, striking, or shaking the infant (shaken baby syndrome or infantile whiplash syndrome), leading to intracranial hemorrhage.

Why Not Others:

  • A) True: It is also known as Caffey-Kempe syndrome.
  • B) False: Battered Baby Syndrome is more common in male children below 3 years of age.
  • C) True: Infantile whiplash syndrome is indeed an example of the syndrome.
  • D) True: Injuries in different stages of healing are often found.

Key Takeaways:

  • Battered Baby Syndrome is characterized by repeated physical injuries from non-accidental violence, predominantly affecting male children under 3 years of age.
  • Parents typically provide inconsistent explanations for injuries, and medical attention is often delayed until the child's condition worsens.

questions.text:
Which of the following sentences is/are FALSE?
a. Uterine souffle is a probable sign of pregnancy
b. Atavism is when child is not resembling like his parents, but resembles like his grandparents
c. Sequence of lochia is Alba-> Serosa -> Rubra
d. Posthumous birth is birth of child out of lawful wedlock or not within a competent time after dissolution of marriage
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Uterine Souffle:
    • A soft blowing murmur synchronous with the mother's pulse, heard during the 4th month of pregnancy.
    • Caused by blood flow through the uterine vessels; it is a probable sign of pregnancy.
  • Atavism:
    • Refers to a child resembling grandparents rather than parents, indicating genetic inheritance from earlier generations.
  • Lochia:
    • Lochia Rubra: Lasts from 1-4 days postpartum, bright red, consisting of blood, fetal membrane shreds, and meconium; heaviest in the first 1-2 hours after birth.
    • Lochia Serosa: Lasts from 5-9 days, watery and pale, containing fewer RBCs but more leukocytes and microorganisms.
    • Lochia Alba: Lasts from 10-15 days, thick, grayish-yellow, then whitish, contains decidual cells, leukocytes, mucus, and microorganisms.
  • Posthumous Birth:
    • Refers to the birth of a child after the death of any or both biological parents, not the birth of a child out of lawful wedlock or after marriage dissolution.

Why Not Others:

  • A) True: Uterine souffle is indeed a probable sign of pregnancy.
  • B) True: Atavism correctly describes a child resembling grandparents instead of parents.
  • C) False: The correct sequence is Rubra → Serosa → Alba; thus, this statement is incorrect.
  • D) False: Posthumous birth specifically refers to birth after the father's death, not related to lawful wedlock.

Key Takeaways:

  • Uterine souffle is an early sign of pregnancy.
  • Atavism involves resemblance to grandparents.
  • The correct lochia sequence is Rubra → Serosa → Alba.

Reference:

https://www.lsd.law/define/posthumous-child

questions.text: Eliciting regular rhythmic contractions of uterus by bimanual examination in early Pregnancy (4 - 8th week) is known as
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Hegar's Sign:
    • Positive between 6-10 weeks of pregnancy.
    • Demonstration involves placing one hand on the abdomen and two fingers in the vagina, feeling the hard cervix, the elastic uterus above, and the soft isthmus in between.
    • Considered a valuable sign of early pregnancy.
  • Palmer's Sign:
    • Regular rhythmic contractions of the uterus can be elicited by bimanual examination as early as 4-8 weeks.
  • Osiander's Sign:
    • Increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices around 8 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Braxton-Hick's Contractions:
    • Intermittent, spasmodic, painless contractions observed rarely before the 3rd month but felt easily after the 4th month.
    • Each contraction lasts about 1 minute with relaxation for 2-3 minutes and can be present even if the fetus is deceased.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Hegar's sign is significant but occurs later (6-10 weeks) and describes a different physical finding.
  • C) Braxton-Hick's contractions are generally not felt until after the 4th month.
  • D) Osiander's sign relates to increased pulsation, not rhythmic contractions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Palmer's sign indicates early pregnancy through elicited contractions by bimanual examination.
  • Hegar's sign and Osiander's sign have specific timelines and findings in pregnancy.
  • Braxton-Hick's contractions are primarily seen in the second trimester and beyond.

questions.text: Fertilisation of two ova discharged from the ovary during the same period of ovulation by separate acts of coitus done at short intervals is
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Superfecundation:
    • Refers to the fertilization of two ova released from the ovary during the same ovulation cycle by separate acts of coitus.
    • May involve two different fathers (heteropaternal superfecundation).
    • Can result in variations in the babies' features and complexion.
  • Superfoetation:
    • Occurs when a second ovum is fertilized during a subsequent ovulation while a woman is already pregnant (1-2 months).
    • One fetus may grow at the expense of another, potentially leading to the other fetus being flattened and retained until labor, known as fetus papyraceus.
  • Supposititious Child:
    • Refers to a fictitious child; a woman may pretend to be pregnant and produce a living child as her own to claim property or financial benefits.
  • Atavism:
    • Involves a child resembling grandparents instead of parents due to the reappearance of genetic characteristics after several generations.

Why Not Others:

  • B) Supposititious child is unrelated to fertilization and concerns deception regarding pregnancy.
  • C) Atavism does not relate to fertilization but to genetic traits appearing after generations.
  • D) Superfoetation is about overlapping pregnancies, not simultaneous fertilization.

Key Takeaways:

  • Superfecundation involves the fertilization of multiple ova during the same ovulatory cycle, potentially by different fathers.
  • Superfoetation describes fertilization occurring while already pregnant, affecting fetal development.
  • Understanding these terms clarifies different reproductive scenarios and their implications.

choices.text: The body and cervix have the same length
The top of fundus is convex and higher level than line of broad ligament
The walls are concave from inside forming wider and rounded cavity
Internal os is circular and well defined.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female was brought for autopsy. On investigation, the investigating officer had heard that she had a female child a few months before normal delivery. The police required additional opinion on 'Whether the female had delivered a child or not?' in addition to the cause of death. Which of the following findings in the uterus will indicate the female has not delivered a child?
questions.solution:
Key Features of a Nulliparous Uterus:

  • Body and Cervix of Same Length:
    Indicates a nulliparous state; the uterus has not undergone changes associated with childbirth.
  • Upper Surface of Fundus Less Convex:
    Typically at the same level as the broad ligament, contrasting with a parous uterus where the fundus is higher.
  • Wall Configuration:
    Concave walls form a smaller, triangular cavity, rather than the wider cavity seen in a parous uterus.
  • Cervical Features:
    • External os is round and appears smooth, resembling a small hollow; this indicates a lack of scarring.
    • Internal os is circular and well-defined, with the mucous membrane intact.

Features of a Parous Uterus:

  • Body Twice the Length of the Cervix:
    This indicates that the uterus has been stretched due to childbirth.
  • Top of Fundus Convex and Higher Level:
    Signifies the adaptation of the uterus to accommodate a previous pregnancy.
  • Walls are Concave:
    Forming a wider and rounded cavity, indicative of previous childbirth.
  • Irregular Cervix with Scars:
    External os is typically transverse and fissured, often admitting the tip of a finger, showing signs of past deliveries.

Why Not Others:

  • B) The top of the fundus is convex and at a higher level than the line of the broad ligament, indicating a parous uterus.
  • C) Concave walls forming a wider cavity suggest a parous uterus.
  • E) A well-defined internal os indicates prior childbirth adaptations.

Key Takeaways:

  • Findings of a nulliparous uterus include equal lengths of body and cervix, round external os, and smooth, intact mucous membranes.
  • Identifying these features is crucial in determining the reproductive history of the individual in autopsy cases.

questions.text:
Choose the correct option regarding the principal signs of virginity.
(i) An intact hymen
(ii) Narrow vagina and rugose walls
(iii) Normal condition of fourchette and posterior commissure
(iv) Normal condition of labia minora and introitus
questions.solution:
Principal Signs of Virginity:

  • Intact Hymen:
    A key indicator often associated with virginity, as it may remain intact in individuals who have not engaged in penetrative sexual intercourse.
  • Narrow Vagina and Rugose Walls:
    A narrower vaginal canal with rugose (folded) walls is typical in virgin females, providing resistance during penetration.
  • Normal Condition of Fourchette and Posterior Commissure:
    The fourchette (the area where the labia minora meet) and the posterior commissure should appear normal, indicating no trauma or scarring.

Why Not Others:

  • Normal Condition of Labia Minora and Introitus (iv):
    While important, this condition alone does not specifically indicate virginity; labia and introitus can appear normal in both virgins and non-virgins.

Key Takeaways:

  • Signs of virginity include an intact hymen, narrow vaginal canal, and normal conditions of specific anatomical structures.
  • Understanding these signs is essential in the context of forensic examinations and social discussions surrounding virginity.

questions.text:
Which of the following options is FALSE regarding abortion?
a. BNS section 89 dealt with abortion without woman's consent
b. Most common cause of first trimester abortion is anatomical abnormality
c. Most common complication of septic abortion is pelvic inflammatory disease
d. Emmenagogues are used to increase uterine contraction
questions.solution:
• Most Common Cause of First Trimester Abortion:
    • FALSE: The most common cause is genetic factors (chromosomal abnormalities), not anatomic abnormalities.
  • Legal Aspects of Abortion:
    • BNS S. 89 deals with abortion without consent.
    • BNS S. 88 addresses abortion with consent.
  • Complications of Abortion:
    • The most common complication of septic abortion is indeed pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • Emmenagogues vs. Ecbolics:
    • Emmenagogues are substances that increase menstrual flow, e.g., borax, savin, sanguinarine.
    • Ecbolics are used to increase uterine contractions, e.g., ergot preparations, strychnine, quinine.

Why Not Others:

  • a & b (i): a is true and b is false. BNS section 89 dealt with abortion without woman's consent and Most Common Cause of First Trimester abortion is genetic factors (chromosomal abnormalities).
  • a & c (iii): Both statements are true; BNS S. 89 does deal with non-consensual abortion, and septic abortion can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • c & d (iv): c is true and d is false. The complication of septic abortion is correctly identified, and the emmenagogues are substances that increase menstrual flow.

Key Takeaways:

  • Genetic factors are the leading cause of first trimester abortions.
  • Understanding the distinctions between ecbolics and emmenagogues is crucial in the context of abortion practices and complications.
  • Legal considerations surrounding abortion are important in forensic and clinical settings.

choices.text: Termination of pregnancy in case of contraceptive failure by married woman only
Opinion of one Registered Medical Practitioner (RMP) for termination of pregnancy up to 20 weeks of gestation.

Increases the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women, including survivors of rape, victims of incest and other vulnerable women (differently abled women, minors, among others).
The Act allows abortion after 24 weeks only in cases where a Medical Board diagnoses substantial foetal abnormalities.

questions.text: According to the recent amendment in the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act in 2021, which of the following statement/s is/are false?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Termination of Pregnancy for Contraceptive Failure:
    • FALSE: The Act allows termination due to contraceptive failure for both married and unmarried women or even in male.
  • Medical Practitioner Opinions:
    • One Registered Medical Practitioner (RMP) can provide an opinion for termination of pregnancy up to 20 weeks.
    • For 20-24 weeks, the opinion of two RMPs is required.
  • Upper Gestation Limit:
    • The amendment increases the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women, including survivors of rape, incest, and vulnerable women (e.g., differently abled, minors).
  • Abortion After 24 Weeks:
    • Abortion after 24 weeks is permissible only in cases diagnosed by a Medical Board for substantial fetal abnormalities.

Why Not Others:

  • All other statements (b, c, d) are true based on the provisions of the amended act.

Key Takeaways:

  • The amendment to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act 2021 broadens access to abortion services, addressing both contraceptive failures and the needs of vulnerable populations.
  • Understanding the nuances of the act is crucial for healthcare providers and legal professionals involved in reproductive health.

choices.text: There are predisposing diseases present in pregnant woman leading to abortion
The injuries on genital organs are absent
The toxic effects of drugs are absent
The frequency of infection is more

questions.text: Which of the following is true about criminal abortion?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Criminal Abortion Characteristics:
  • Infection Frequency:
    • TRUE: The frequency of infection is higher in cases of criminal abortion due to unsafe practices and potential introduction of pathogens.
  • Comparative Features:


Why Not Others:

  • A: Predisposing diseases are more commonly associated with natural abortion, not criminal abortion.
  • B: Injuries to genital organs are often present in criminal abortion due to unsafe procedures.
  • C: Toxic effects of drugs are typically associated with criminal abortion due to the use of unsafe substances.

Key Takeaways:

  • Criminal abortions are characterized by higher risks of infection and potential injuries due to unsafe practices.
  • Understanding the differences between natural and criminal abortions is essential for medical professionals in providing appropriate care and support.

questions.text: NOT a surgical method of choice in 1st trimester abortion under MTP Act is
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Hysterotomy:
    • Incorrect: This method is primarily used in the 2nd trimester and not suitable for 1st trimester abortions.
  • Preferred Surgical Methods for 1st Trimester Abortion:
    • Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA): Commonly used and effective for abortions up to 12 weeks.
    • Suction Evacuation and/or Curettage: Also utilized for early abortions but less favored than MVA.
  • Methods of inducing abortion under MTP Act


Why Not Others:

  • C) Dilatation and evacuation: Used for later gestations, primarily from 12-14 weeks.
  • D) Suction evacuation and/or curettage: Effective but not the first choice compared to MVA.

Key Takeaways:

  • Manual Vacuum Aspiration is the preferred surgical method for first trimester abortions.
  • Understanding the appropriate methods for each trimester is crucial for compliance with the MTP Act and ensuring patient safety.

choices.text: Opinion about impotency should be given in double negative form
Permanent erectile dysfunction is ground for nullity of marriage
Bulbocavernosus reflex test is done to determine hormonal factors of the erectile dysfunction
Nocturnal penile tumescence testing is useful in distinguishing psychogenic from organic impotence

questions.text: Which of the following sentence is FALSE regarding impotence?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Bulbocavernosus Reflex Test:
    • False Statement: This test assesses nerve sensation in the penis, not hormonal factors. It evaluates nerve function by checking the reflex response when the glans is squeezed.
  • Indian Law and Erectile Dysfunction:
    • Permanent erectile dysfunction (ED) can be a ground for nullity of marriage due to incapacity to consummate the marriage.
    • Development of ED after consummation is not a ground for divorce.
  • Opinion on ED:
    • An opinion on impotence should be expressed in double negative form. For instance, stating there is nothing to suggest that the person is incapable of performing sexual intercourse.
  • Nocturnal Penile Tumescence Testing:
    • Evaluates erectile function during sleep; absence of normal erections may indicate organic issues rather than psychogenic causes.

Why Not Others:

  • A) True: Opinion should be given in double negative form.
  • B) True: Permanent ED can be a ground for nullity of marriage.
  • D) True: Nocturnal penile tumescence testing helps differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bulbocavernosus Reflex Test is not for hormonal assessment but for evaluating nerve function.
  • Understanding the legal and clinical implications of erectile dysfunction is essential in medical and legal contexts.

choices.text: Prohibited degree of relationship (unless custom permits)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a ground for void marriage?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Void Marriage (null from inception):
    • Bigamy: Entering a second marriage without dissolving the first.
    • Sapinda Relationship: Relationships extending to the third generation through the mother or fifth generation through the father.
    • Prohibited Degree of Relationship: Marriages between relatives (by blood) are void unless permitted by custom.
  • Voidable Marriage (valid until annulled):
    • Conditions such as impotence, unsoundness of mind, or consent obtained through force or fraud.
    • Pregnancy of the female by another man without the husband's knowledge at the time of marriage.
  • Grounds for Divorce (not grounds for void marriage):
    • Cruelty: Wilful conduct causing danger to life or health, including mental health.
    • Other grounds include adultery, desertion, apostasy, and others.

Why Not Others:

  • A) True: Bigamy is a ground for void marriage.
  • B) True: Sapinda relationship makes a marriage void.
  • C) True: Prohibited degree of relationship is a ground for void marriage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cruelty is a valid ground for divorce but does not render a marriage void.
  • Understanding the distinction between void and voidable marriages is crucial for legal implications in marital disputes.

questions.text: The impotency of a male towards one particular female and not with another is known as
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Quod (Impotence Quod Hanc): Refers to the inability of a male to perform sexually with one specific female while being able to do so with others.
  • Frigidity: This term describes a female's inability to achieve sexual arousal or orgasm, indicating a lack of desire for sexual intercourse.
  • Erectile Dysfunction: Defined as the consistent inability to attain or maintain an erection sufficient for sexual intercourse.
  • Premature Ejaculation: Characterized by a male's early ejaculation during sexual activity, occurring sooner than desired.

Why Not Others:

  • B) Frigidity does not pertain to male impotence; it relates to female sexual dysfunction.
  • C) Erectile dysfunction refers to a general condition affecting the male's ability to achieve an erection, not specific to an individual.
  • D) Premature ejaculation involves timing of ejaculation, not impotence with a specific partner.

Key Takeaways:

  • Quod is a unique condition reflecting specific impotence towards one female, distinguishing it from general sexual dysfunction terms.
  • Understanding these distinctions aids in the accurate assessment of sexual health issues.

choices.text: The child born through Artificial Insemination by Donor is illegitimate
The child born through Artificial Insemination by Husband with stored sperm of deceased husband is illegitimate
Artificial insemination by donor does not amount to adultery
Artificial insemination is a ground of divorce, if done for sterility

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Artificial Insemination by donor/Artificial Insemination by husband is true?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Adultery and Consent: Artificial insemination by donor (AID) used with the consent of the husband does not constitute adultery for the wife, as there is no physical union by coitus involved.
  • Legitimacy of Child: A child born through AID is presumed legitimate and born within wedlock, given the consent of both spouses, entitling the child to rights of parentage, support, and inheritance.
  • Stored Sperm from Deceased Husband: A child born through artificial insemination with the stored sperm of a deceased husband is still considered legitimate.
  • Grounds for Divorce: AID is not a ground for divorce if performed for sterility. However, if done without the husband's consent, he may file for divorce and take legal action against the doctor.

Why Not Others:

  • A) The child from AID is not illegitimate when the husband consents.
  • B) The child from AID with deceased husband's sperm is considered legitimate.
  • D) AID does not constitute grounds for divorce if done to address sterility.

Key Takeaways:

  • Consent in artificial insemination is crucial for determining legitimacy and legality.
  • Adultery is not applicable in AID with spousal consent, emphasizing the non-physical nature of the procedure.

choices.text: The husband should be between 26-55 years
The wife should be between 23-50 years
The intending woman should be between 35-45 years to avail surrogacy service
The surrogate mother can be an Indian or non-citizen of India

questions.text: Which of the following statement is FALSE according to The Surrogacy Act, 2021?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Intending Couple Definition: An "intending couple" is defined as a couple with a medical condition that necessitates gestational surrogacy and who intend to become parents through surrogacy.
  • Eligibility Criteria:
    • Husband's Age: Must be between 26-55 years.
    • Wife's Age: Must be between 23-50 years.
    • Intending Woman's Age: Must be between 35-45 years for surrogacy services.
  • Surrogacy Eligibility: The Act specifies that only Indian intending couples can avail of surrogacy services, excluding non-citizens or foreign individuals. The surrogate mother should also be of Indian origin.

Why Not Others:

  • A) The husband's age requirement (26-55 years) is true.
  • B) The wife's age requirement (23-50 years) is true.
  • C) The age requirement for the intending woman (35-45 years) is accurate.

Key Takeaways:

  • Surrogacy Regulations: The Surrogacy Act, 2021 emphasizes specific age criteria for intending couples and restricts surrogacy services to Indian citizens.
  • Intending Couples: Understanding the legal definitions and eligibility criteria helps clarify who can legally seek surrogacy in India.

questions.text: Not a ground for Nullity of marriage is, at the time of marriage, either of the party is/has
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Adultery: While adultery is a valid ground for divorce, it does not establish grounds for the nullity of marriage.
  • Grounds for Nullity of marriage:
    • Impotence: If either of the party is impotent at the time of marriage.
    • Intellectual Disability: If either of the party is suffering from intellectual disability.
    • Pregnancy: If either of the party is pregnant by someone other than the respondent.
    • Below Marriageable Age: Either party is below the legal marriageable age.
    • Already Married: If either of the party is already married (bigamy).

Legal Framework:

  • Hindu Marriage Act, Section 5: Specifies conditions for valid marriage, including:
    • Spouse Living: Neither party can have a living spouse at the time of marriage.
    • Valid Consent: Must be capable of giving valid consent; unsoundness of mind is a factor.
    • Age: Bridegroom must be 21 years, and bride must be 18 years.
    • Prohibited Relationships: Parties must not be within prohibited degrees of relationship.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Suffering from intellectual disability can prove nullity.
  • B) Below marriageable age can prove nullity.
  • C) Already married can prove nullity.

Key Takeaways:

  • Nullity vs. Divorce: Understanding the distinction between grounds for nullity (invalid marriage) and divorce (dissolving a valid marriage) is crucial in matrimonial law.
  • Legal Conditions: Familiarity with the requirements under the Hindu Marriage Act is essential for determining the validity of a marriage.

choices.text: It is a type of paraphilia.
The person gets sexual gratification when painful stimulus is received from opposite partner
Sadistic crime scenes include torture, use of weapon, humiliation, victim confinement, bondage etc.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Sadism is NOT true?
questions.solution:
• Definition of Sadism: Sadism involves deriving sexual gratification from inflicting pain or suffering on others, not from receiving pain.
  • Comparison with Masochism: In Masochism, individuals gain sexual pleasure from receiving pain, contrasting with Sadism.
  • Common Practices: Sadistic individuals may engage in acts such as beating, biting, whipping, and other forms of physical cruelty.
  • Demographics: Sadism is commonly observed in males.
  • Crime Scene Characteristics: Typical features of sadistic crime scenes include:
    • Torture
    • Use of weapons
    • Humiliation
    • Victim confinement
    • Bondage
    • Expressive violence
    • Post-death physical and sexual mutilation
    • Object insertion into the vagina

Why Not Others:

  • A) True: Sadism is recognized as a type of paraphilia.
  • C) True: It is more commonly found in males.
  • D) True: Sadistic crime scenes often exhibit the described violent features.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding Sadism: Recognizing the distinction between Sadism and Masochism is crucial in the context of paraphilias.
  • Behavioral Characteristics: Knowledge of common behaviors and crime scene features associated with Sadism aids in forensic and psychological assessments.

questions.text: The disorder characterized by recurrent, intense, sexually arousing fantasies, sexual urges or behaviours involving cross-dressing is called
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Definition: Transvestic fetishism (or Eonism) involves recurrent, intense sexual fantasies and behaviors associated with cross-dressing.
  • Mechanism of Gratification: Sexual gratification is derived from wearing clothing typically associated with the opposite sex.
  • Distinction from Transsexualism: Unlike transsexuals, who dress as the opposite sex due to a genuine identification with that gender, transvestites do so primarily for sexual excitement.
  • Prevalence: This condition is usually observed in males.
  • Related Disorders:
    • Sadomasochism: Involves the interplay of sadism and masochism, often with one being dominant.
    • Frotteurism: Involves sexual arousal from rubbing against a non-consenting person in public.
    • Onanism (Masturbation): Refers to the self-stimulation of the genitals for sexual pleasure.

Why Not Others:

  • B) Frotteurism: Specifically involves non-consensual rubbing against another person.
  • C) Onanism: Refers to masturbation, not cross-dressing or fetishes.
  • D) Sadomasochism: Focuses on the dynamics of sadism and masochism rather than cross-dressing.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding Transvestic Fetishism: Recognizing the specific behaviours and motivations behind transvestic fetishism is crucial for appropriate assessment and treatment.
  • Differentiating Disorders: Clear differentiation from other paraphilias helps in understanding individual sexual behaviors and urges.

questions.text: The morbid desire of an individual to observe unsuspecting people undress or naked, taking bath, see the genitalia or watch intercourse to get erotic excitement and sexual gratification is called
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Definition: Voyeurism (Scotophilia) is characterized by the desire to observe others without their consent, particularly during intimate moments, to achieve sexual excitement and gratification.
  • Demographics: It is most commonly seen in males and is punishable under BNS Section 77.

Related Disorders:

  • Frotteurism: Involves obtaining sexual arousal by rubbing one's genitals against a non-consenting person in public places.
  • Exhibitionism: Refers to the urge to expose one's genitals to others, often in public settings, primarily for sexual pleasure; often called flashers and punishable under BNS Sec. 296 (Obscene act).
  • Fetishism: Involves a sexual fixation on inanimate objects or specific body parts that are not inherently sexual, necessitating their presence for sexual gratification (e.g., handkerchiefs, undergarments).

Why Not Others:

  • A) Frotteurism: Focuses on physical contact with a non-consenting individual rather than observation.
  • C) Exhibitionism: Involves displaying oneself sexually rather than watching others.
  • D) Fetishism: Centers on objects or body parts for sexual arousal, not the act of observing others.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding Voyeurism: Recognizing voyeurism's nature is essential for effective intervention and treatment, particularly due to its non-consensual aspect.
  • Legal Implications: Awareness of legal consequences highlights the serious nature of these behaviors.

questions.text: Indecent assault is punishable under which section of BNS?
questions.solution:
• Definition: Indecent assault refers to any unwanted sexual behaviour or touching of a female without her consent, aimed at outraging her modesty.
  • Examples: It can range from inappropriate touching to more severe acts, such as sexual harassment, and includes scenarios like touching someone's buttocks in a crowded setting.
  • Punishment: It is punishable under BNS Sec. 74 with a penalty of 1 to 5 years imprisonment, along with a possible fine.

Related Sections:

  • Sec. 75: Covers Frotteurism/Sexual harassment, punishable by up to 3 years and/or a fine.
  • Sec. 76: Pertains to Disrobing, with a punishment of 3 to 7 years and/or a fine.
  • Sec. 77: Addresses Voyeurism, carrying a punishment of 1 to 3 years for the first offense and 3 to 7 years for subsequent offenses.
  • Sec. 78: Relates to Stalking, with penalties of up to 3 years for the first offense and up to 5 years for subsequent offenses.

Key Takeaways:

  • Legal Definition: Understanding the legal framework surrounding indecent assault is crucial for both victims and legal practitioners.
  • Consequences: The section outlines the seriousness of the offense and the potential penalties involved, reflecting societal values on consent and personal boundaries.

questions.text: The recurrent, intense fantasies, urges or behaviours involving sexual activity with a prepubescent child or children (less than 13 years) by a person who is more than 16 years and at least 5 years older than the child is called
questions.solution:
• Definition: Pedophilia is characterized by recurrent, intense sexual fantasies, urges, or behaviors involving sexual activity with a prepubescent child (under 13 years) by an individual who is more than 16 years old and at least 5 years older than the child.
  • Demographics: Pedophiles are primarily male and may be attracted to either gender of children.
  • Comparison with Other Terms:
    • Gerontophilia: A sexual preference for the elderly.
    • Urophilia (Urolagnia): Involves sexual gratification from urine or urination, often referred to as "golden showers."
    • Coprophilia: A morbid attraction to feces, where sexual gratification is obtained from the smell, taste, or feel of feces; eating feces is known as coprophagia.

Why Not Others:

  • B) Urophilia: This refers to sexual arousal from urine or urination, not sexual activity with children, making it unrelated to the definition of pedophilia.
  • C) Coprophilia: This involves sexual gratification derived from feces, which is distinct from the sexual interest in children and does not match the criteria of pedophilia.
  • D) Gerontophilia: This term denotes a sexual attraction to elderly individuals, which is the opposite of the focus on prepubescent children in pedophilia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding Pedophilia: Recognizing pedophilia as a psychological disorder is essential for mental health professionals and legal systems to address and prevent child exploitation.
  • Distinction of Terms: Differentiating between paraphilias can help in the understanding of sexual preferences and their implications for individuals and society.

questions.text: Rape is defined under which section of BNS?
questions.solution:
• Definition: Rape is defined under BNS Sec. 63.
  • Punishment: BNS Sec. 64 specifies the punishment for rape.
  • Other Sections:
    • BNS Sec. 67: Addresses sexual intercourse by a husband upon his wife during separation.
    • BNS Sec. 68: Pertains to sexual intercourse by a person of authority.

Why Not Others:

  • B) 64: This section relates to the punishment for rape, not the definition itself.
  • C) 67: This section focuses on a specific scenario of sexual intercourse during separation, unrelated to the definition of rape.
  • D) 68: This section deals with sexual intercourse by a person in a position of authority, in a position of authority, taking advantage of his official position to induce/seduce any woman to have sexual intercourse with him, not amounting to rape. This section does not define rape.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding Rape Legislation: Knowledge of the relevant legal sections is crucial for understanding the definitions and consequences of sexual offenses.
  • Importance of Specificity: Distinguishing between sections that define acts versus those that outline punishments helps in legal clarity and enforcement.

questions.text: Which of the following sections of BNS is related to dowry deaths?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • BNS Sec. 80: Specifically addresses Dowry Deaths.
  • BNS Sec. 81: Pertains to cohabitation induced by deceitful belief of lawful marriage.
  • BNS Sec. 82: Relates to marrying again while the spouse is still alive.
  • BNS Sec. 79: Concerns acts intended to insult a woman's modesty.

Why Not Others:

  • A) 79: This section focuses on insulting modesty, which does not address dowry deaths.
  • C) 81: Deals with deception regarding marriage, unrelated to the issue of dowry.
  • D) 82: Pertains to remarriage during the lifetime of an existing spouse, not related to dowry deaths.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understanding Dowry Deaths: Awareness of the specific legal provisions regarding dowry deaths is essential for addressing and preventing such cases.
  • Legal Clarity: Identifying sections accurately ensures proper understanding and enforcement of laws related to women's rights and safety.

choices.text: (i) is true and (ii) is false
(i) is false and (ii) is true

questions.text:
(i) Soon after sexual intercourse, the torn margins are sharp, red and bleed on touch.
(ii) Signs of recent rupture of hymen are ragged tears in the hymen with epithelial healing, edema and haemorrhage
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • (i): True - Following sexual intercourse, the torn margins of the hymen are indeed sharp, red, and can bleed on touch. After 3-4 days, the edges appear swollen, congested, and smaller.
  • (ii): False - Recent hymenal rupture does show ragged tears but there is a lack of epithelial healing at this stage, along with edema and hemorrhage.

Why Not Others:

  • B) (i) is false and (ii) is true: Incorrect, as (i) accurately describes the condition post-intercourse.
  • C) (i) and (ii) are true: Incorrect, as (ii) misrepresents the state of epithelial healing post-rupture.
  • D) (i) and (ii) are false: Incorrect, as (i) is true.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hymenal Examination: Understanding the characteristics of hymenal tears post-intercourse is critical in medical examinations.
  • Differentiating Conditions: Properly identifying the healing status of the hymen aids in distinguishing between recent and older injuries.

questions.text: In case of sexual offences, 1% Toluidine blue is used to detect _______. in vagina.
questions.solution:
• Local Examination: Conducted to identify injuries in cases of sexual offenses.
  • Detection Method: Injuries are assessed using tools like a magnifying glass or colposcope.
  • Toluidine Blue Application: Spraying 1% Toluidine blue highlights subtle injuries by staining them blue, making them more visible during examination.
  • Importance of Timing: This test should be performed after swabs for trace evidence have been collected to avoid contamination.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Fungal growth: Incorrect because Toluidine blue is not specifically used for detecting fungal infections.
  • B) Microblisters: Incorrect; while microblisters can be identified during examination, Toluidine blue specifically aids in revealing microabrasions.
  • D) Warts: Incorrect as warts typically do not require Toluidine blue for identification; they can be visually observed.

Key Takeaways:

  • Forensic Importance: Understanding the use of specific stains like Toluidine blue is crucial in forensic examinations for effectively documenting injuries.
  • Identification of Subtle Injuries: Toluidine blue is valuable for detecting microabrasions, which may be significant evidence in sexual offense cases.
  • Procedure Protocol: Adhering to proper examination protocols ensures accurate collection of evidence and supports legal processes in sexual offense cases.

questions.text: Glycoprotein p30 is detected from which of the following samples?
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Definition of p30: Also known as Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA), p30 is a glycoprotein derived from the prostate.
  • Sample Origin: Found in seminal plasma, male urine, and blood; it is not present in any female body tissue or fluid.
  • Identification: p30 reliably identifies semen, even when other tests, such as acid phosphatase or the presence of spermatozoa, may not be conclusive.
  • Detection Method: Assessed serologically using specific antisera for the p30 antigen.
  • Persistence in Samples:
    • Detectable in vaginal fluid for up to 27 hours (range 13-47 hours) after intercourse, compared to 12-14 hours for acid phosphatase.
    • Can be detected in dried and old stains (more than 10 years old, even when stored at room temperature) and in cadavers.

Why Not Others:

  • B) Plucked nails: Incorrect; nails do not contain p30 as it is prostate-derived.
  • C) Root of body hairs: Incorrect; p30 is not present in hair follicles.
  • D) Vitreous humour: Incorrect; this fluid does not contain p30 as it is not related to prostatic secretions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Forensic Relevance: The detection of p30 is crucial in forensic investigations involving sexual assault or semen identification.
  • Long-lasting Detection: Its stability in dried stains makes it a reliable marker for forensic analysis, even after significant time has passed.
  • Specificity: The specific identification of p30 enhances the accuracy of evidence related to semen presence in legal contexts.

questions.text: The saliva/salivary stains of the accused in sexual offence is used to determine the___.
questions.solution:
Key Points:

  • Purpose of Analysis: Salivary stains found on bite marks, cigarette ends, or clothing can help determine the secretor status of an individual.
  • Secretor Status: Refers to the ability of a person to secrete blood group antigens in their saliva and other bodily fluids. This can provide valuable information in forensic investigations.
  • Identification Method:
    • Alpha Amylase Test: Salivary stains are identified by testing for the presence of alpha amylase, an enzyme commonly found in saliva.
  • Forensic Importance: Establishing secretor status can link a suspect to a crime scene and assist in corroborating other evidence.

Why Not Others:

  • B) HIV status: Incorrect; saliva analysis does not provide information about an individual's HIV status.
  • C) Oral infection: Incorrect; while saliva may indicate certain infections, it is not specifically used for forensic determination in criminal cases.
  • D) Sexually transmitted disease: Incorrect; saliva is not a reliable indicator of sexually transmitted diseases.

Key Takeaways:

  • Forensic Relevance: Understanding secretor status can be crucial in linking suspects to crimes involving saliva evidence.
  • Analytical Significance: Testing for alpha amylase enhances the reliability of forensic analysis in sexual offence cases.
  • Evidence Correlation: This method aids in establishing connections between the suspect and the crime, supporting the overall investigation.
